block.p: Cable Dispute Halts Service To Time Warner Customers Millions of television viewers in major markets, including New York and Los Angeles, found themselves without access to ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire'' and many other popular TV programs as Time Warner and Walt Disney fought over how much Disney should be paid for its cable programming.

The dispute also involved issues concerning the distribution of news and entertainment programming, the growing competition between cable and satellite companies, and Disney's opposition to the proposed merger of America Online and Time Warner. ABC asked the Federal Communications Commission to restore programming. [Page A1.]

Actors Stop Work on Commercials The Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists went on strike and called on their membership of about 135,000 actors to stop working on all television and radio commercials until an agreement could be reached with advertisers. Actors rallied in Los Angeles, New York, Chicago and San Francisco. [C2.]
Mexico Revamps Bankruptcy Laws The Mexican Congress has passed legislation to replace bankruptcy and loan-guarantee laws dating to the 1940's. [C4.]

Stocks Climb in Calm Session Major market gauges remained in positive territory in a session devoid of volatility. The Dow Jones industrial average was up 77.87 points, or 0.7 percent, to 10,811.78. The Nasdaq composite closed at 3,958.08, up 97.42 points, or 2.5 percent, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 15.82 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,468.25. [C14.]

Lehman Brothers Is Named in Suit Lehman Brothers, a source of financing for lenders catering to customers with less than perfect credit, was named in a class-action suit filed against First Alliance, a national mortgage lender that filed for bankruptcy protection in March. [C10.]

Rexall Agrees to $1.7 Billion Deal The Dutch vitamin maker Royal Numico N.V. agreed to buy Rexall Sundown Inc. for about $1.7 billion, bolstering its No. 1 position in the American vitamin and nutritional supplement market. Numico, best known as Europe's top baby food maker, entered the vitamin market last year. Shares of Rexall Sundown rose $4.1875, to $23.4375. [C4.]

Reports Suggest Economy Is Strong A picture of a strong economy emerged from figures released by the National Association of Purchasing Management on growth in manufacturing in April, along with a government report of a surprising 1.4 percent rise in construction spending in March, to a seasonally adjusted annual pace of $765.2 billion. [C8.]

Realism in Fast-Food Advertising Cliff Freeman and Partners, known for offbeat commercials like ''Where's the Beef?'' for Wendy's, is serving up a television campaign for Church's Fried Chicken that tries to depict working families realistically. The spots at first appear to be film clips rather than commercials. Advertising. [C12.]
